meta.title: Linear Equations in Two Variables - Exercise 4.4 (Long Answer Questions)

questions.question: Show that the points $A(1, 2), B(-1, -16)$ and $C(0, -7)$ lie on the graph of the linear equation $y = 9x - 7$.
questions.solution:
We have the linear equation $y = 9x - 7$.

To show that the points lie on the graph, we check if their coordinates satisfy the equation.

  • For A(1, 2): Put $x = 1, y = 2$.
    RHS $= 9(1) - 7 = 9 - 7 = 2 = $ LHS.
    So, A(1, 2) lies on the graph.
  • For B(-1, -16): Put $x = -1, y = -16$.
    RHS $= 9(-1) - 7 = -9 - 7 = -16 = $ LHS.
    So, B(-1, -16) lies on the graph.
  • For C(0, -7): Put $x = 0, y = -7$.
    RHS $= 9(0) - 7 = 0 - 7 = -7 = $ LHS.
    So, C(0, -7) lies on the graph.

questions.question: The following observed values of $x$ and $y$ are thought to satisfy a linear equation. Write the linear equation:
parts: Draw the graph using the values of $x, y$ as given in the above table. At what points the graph of the linear equation (i) cuts the X-axis? (ii) cuts the Y-axis?
questions.solution:
Let the linear equation be $y = mx + c$.

Substituting $(6, -2)$: $-2 = 6m + c$ ... (i)

Substituting $(-6, 6)$: $6 = -6m + c$ ... (ii)

Adding (i) and (ii): $4 = 2c \Rightarrow c = 2$.

From (i): $-2 = 6m + 2 \Rightarrow 6m = -4 \Rightarrow m = -\frac{2}{3}$.

So, equation is $y = -\frac{2}{3}x + 2$ or $3y = -2x + 6 \Rightarrow 2x + 3y = 6$.

(i) Cuts X-axis: Put $y = 0$. $2x = 6 \Rightarrow x = 3$. Point is $(3, 0)$.

(ii) Cuts Y-axis: Put $x = 0$. $3y = 6 \Rightarrow y = 2$. Point is $(0, 2)$.

questions.question: Draw the graph of the linear equation $3x + 4y = 6$. At what points, the graph cuts the X-axis and the Y-axis?
questions.solution:
Equation: $3x + 4y = 6$.

Cuts X-axis: Put $y = 0$.
$3x = 6 \Rightarrow x = 2$.
Point: $(2, 0)$.

Cuts Y-axis: Put $x = 0$.
$4y = 6 \Rightarrow y = \frac{6}{4} = 1.5$.
Point: $(0, 1.5)$.

Plot these points $(2, 0)$ and $(0, 1.5)$ on the graph and join them to get the line.

questions.question: The linear equation that converts Fahrenheit (F) to Celsius (C) is given by the relation $C = \frac{5F - 160}{9}$.
parts: (i) If the temperature is $86^\circ F$, what is the temperature in Celsius?
(ii) If the temperature is $35^\circ C$, what is the temperature in Fahrenheit?
(iii) If the temperature is $0^\circ C$, what is the temperature in Fahrenheit and if the temperature is $0^\circ F$, what is the temperature in Celsius?
(iv) What is the numerical value of the temperature which is same in both the scales?
questions.solution:
• (i) Put $F = 86$:
    $C = \frac{5(86) - 160}{9} = \frac{430 - 160}{9} = \frac{270}{9} = 30^\circ C$.
  • (ii) Put $C = 35$:
    $35 = \frac{5F - 160}{9} \Rightarrow 315 = 5F - 160 \Rightarrow 5F = 475 \Rightarrow F = 95^\circ F$.
  • (iii) If $C = 0$: $0 = \frac{5F - 160}{9} \Rightarrow 5F = 160 \Rightarrow F = 32^\circ F$.
    If $F = 0$: $C = \frac{-160}{9} \approx -17.8^\circ C$.
  • (iv) Let $F = C = x$.
    $x = \frac{5x - 160}{9} \Rightarrow 9x = 5x - 160 \Rightarrow 4x = -160 \Rightarrow x = -40$.
    So, $-40^\circ$ is the same in both scales.

questions.question: If the temperature of a liquid can be measured in Kelvin units as $x$ K or in Fahrenheit units as $y$ F, the relation between the two systems of measurement of temperature is given by the linear equation $y = \frac{9}{5}(x - 273) + 32$.
parts: (i) Find the temperature of the liquid in Fahrenheit if the temperature of the liquid is 313 K.
(ii) If the temperature is 158 F, find the temperature in Kelvin.

questions.question: The force exerted to pull a cart is directly proportional to the acceleration produced in the body. Express the statement as a linear equation of two variables and draw the graph of the same by taking the constant mass equal to 6 kg. Read from the graph, the force required when the acceleration produced is (i) $5 m/sec^2$, (ii) $6 m/sec^2$.
questions.solution:
Let Force be $y$ and Acceleration be $x$.

Given $y \propto x \Rightarrow y = kx$.

Here, constant mass $k = 6$. So, equation is $y = 6x$.

Graph: Plot points like $(0, 0), (1, 6), (2, 12)$. It is a straight line passing through origin.

  • (i) When $x = 5$: $y = 6(5) = 30$ N.
  • (ii) When $x = 6$: $y = 6(6) = 36$ N.
